comments.commentBody: I agree, but this assumes politics is not contagious or perhaps that Greece will be hurt so much by its own currency that the Euro will be strengthened elsewhere.    And it assumes the European economy will start improving significantly now.   Maybe yes, maybe no.  But the US experience is worrisome.   With the growth we have seen there was an opposition landslide in 2014 and Christie will have a near landslide in 2016.   And this is with success.   The European electorate by all the evidence is in an uglier mood, and Europe has more radical parties and few checks and balances.

I think I had the same problem: why does the clue say it's 'the start' of the list listing? Also, why specify it's an 'oral' listing?

It seemed to me those tow words were irrelevant, and therefore extraneous. Anyone see a reason that they're included?

It is true that people buy electronics even though they are certain will be lower if they wait.  This suggests that the aggregate demand is sound, but that Krugman's obsession with deflation is much more dubious.   To be sure, loans such as mortgage are harder to repay, but there are a number of ways to solve that problem.

That photo resembles Riverside, CA, where I grew up during the '50s and '60s, prior to the gov't. requiring air pollutant emission controls.

We used to suffer coughing fits after spending an afternoon swimming in our pool. I thought that it was caused by fumes from the chlorine in the water. Then one day I had a coughing fit after mowing the lawn, and I realized that the problem was caused by the air pollution. I escaped to a clean-air place in 1977.

When I worked in a Federal agency, we were enjoined to be extremely careful not to release personal information about employees ("Privacy Act"). Even information that was already publicly available, such as home addresses and listed telephone numbers could not be released.

I can understand how Healthcare.gov and insurance companies that participate in Obamacare need some Privacy Act information in order to perform their roles as government agents. However, releasing such information to Google, Facebook, Twitter, etc., strikes me as blatant violations of law. The people who release such information should be called to account and sternly disciplined. Such information leaks must be stopped.
Acting without mascara! My, what some people will do for an Oscar...

Economic reform cannot take place until there is social reform.  In a global economy, large government run businesses and services can no longer compete with smaller, private, foreign business.  Even the trinkets at the Colleseum are made by small Asian companies.

The Greek people have sent a message to the world's financial oligarchs that they will no longer tolerate being made to pay for the bad faith of others.

It takes two to make a bad debt, and these days the lender is as likely to be culpable as the borrower. Why refuse to make a loan when you can profit from it either way? You either earn interest or if the borrower defaults you can seize assets for pennies on the dollar. Greece's debt can certainly be laid at the door of the county's financial and political elites, but the ordinary people have had to pay both for their corruption and the bad faith of the lenders, who have never shown any inclination to share in any sacrifice.

Now the Greeks will negotiate as equals, not supplicants. Greece invented democracy, and now just maybe she has reinvented it on behalf of ordinary people everywhere.

All that is gold is not silver and all that is silver is green.

All this side show shows is that New York State could cut down government expenses by having only three people run for office once and then once every death of one. It could be called the "Troika."

And the three elected gods would select a personal representative to replace them temporarily when they get caught.

After the trial, appeal and then second appeal, the case will be overturned on a technicality. By that point, someone else will be in charge of the Goose which lays the golden, silver, and green eggs.

Save your efforts hoping for any justice, morality, ethics or democracy in this State or the Nation. So let's just hope the Jets and Giantsor or whichever teams have a great Super Bowl for this annual diversionary Bread and Circus.

At least the Greeks are no longer willing to take it on their Acropolian chin. Maybe Americans will start to loosen the chains of the propaganda of the last 35 years and demand a real democracy of, by and for the People.
Which official is bigger than the fish they have already caught in their net?  I can't see what kind of deal he can cut that will be useful.

jimkinglaw: You're looking at this the wrong way, regarding this persons of "consequence." According to this Washington Post article (http://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/govbeat/wp/2014/01/22/the-most-corru... NY ranks second in # of convicted public officials: 704. The Public Good could be well served if Sheldon drops enough dimes to raise this to, ah, 800. Now, that's what I call a silver lining.

comments.commentBody:
I would guess Speaker Sheldon Silver is through. My former Mount Sinai physician, Dr. Robert N. Taub, was given immunity from prosecution and will deliver. Dr. Taub will not go to jail if he is honest and delivers. Sheldon Silver knows what's coming. His counsel must now negotiate. Fast. Sheldon Silver must offer information of value to stay out of jail. The retiring Speaker will be invited to proffer. His willingness and ability to implicate others of consequence may keep him out of jail. We the people will soon learn what he knows, who else will be arrested, whether or not the Moreland break down will lead to this governor, and who else will be implicated.

Is it possible that Albany will be cleansed?

I shall not hold my breath.

@Jasmine Horn: it means that there are hundreds of independently-made movies that are directed, written and acted without a whole lot of inspiration but whose makers believe that they're saying something useful about the human condition.  "Still Alice" was another recent one. Critics hate to dump on movies like these because doing so makes them feel as if they're lacking in compassion for those suffering from a disease (or poverty or political oppression or whatever).  They should resist such pangs of guilt and just say what they mean. I'm sure that Ms. Aniston, for one, can live with yet another negative review.

Yes, rounding. But secondly, how is you you just arbitrarily pick and choose which numbers to adjust up or down? And even for that matter, how exactly does it make the premise disappear? It doesn't change any relationships among the numbers.

As for "slowing" - so? The point, as is the conventionally accepted observation, is that the middle class has been eroding for decades. But it seems you;re missing the further dramatic point that was th focus of this article.

The trend over time, as reflected in the graphs, is that the "decay of middle class house holds" was predominantly due to households moving out of "middle class" and into "high". This is a GOOD thing! Yes? The whole upward mobility thing and all exemplified.

But what happens in '00 is that households STOP moving up into the "high" bracket (!) and instead start falling into the "Low".

This is indicated by the"High" beginning to fall and "Low" reversing it's gradual decline and ticking upward (!). That is, it went from good, bypassing "neutral" (neither moving into high nor falling into low), and going straight to bad with people falling out of the middle class and into "Low".
Right-wing contortionist?

First of all, the percentages for 2000 and 2013 don't even add up to 100.

In 2000: the percentages add up to 101% and in 2013 they add up to 99%.

I'm sure this is due to rounding, but if you round down the middle class number from 2000 and round up the middle class number from 2013, the percentages add up to 100% and the entire premise of the story disappears.

Another thing the charts show is that the shrinking of the middle class is actually slowing down over the last four years, as is the rise in lower income households. If anything, the data shows that things are stabilizing after a decade long period ( 2000 - 2009 ) of getting worse.

Not surprising because every other bit of economic data that comes out reaches the same conclusion: the 2000s were awful, and now there is change. And with change, comes hope.

Sorry but it is impolite to address a politically cojoined twin without acknowledging the other.

It is NOT illegal or unethical for a doctor or lawyer to refer patients or clients to each other. Lawyers know 1st hand who are the best doctors and vice versa for a given injury, illness etc... That's permitted so long as no $ is involved. Without real proof - emails recordings etc... it will be difficult to prove beyond a reasonable doubt that funding the research center was done solely to get patients. You really think SS is gonna say he did demanded patients or that he decided to help one of the best research facilities trying to treat or find a cure for this illness?
Bottom line the shame of this all is a research center being shut.
Failure to Disclose?

comments.userLocation: Lewis Family Farm, Essex, New York
comments.commentBody:
Dr. Robert N. Taub and his wife were in this for themselves. And their son.

He's done in medicine. And fund raising. Columbia College of Physicians & Surgeons sacked him. At 78 and inside Columbia University, he is shut down.

Speaker Sheldon Silver put ethic aside for money, broke the law. He disgraced The State of New York and his people. Two Orthodox Jews misbehaving. And they show no shame.

Mendacious criminality.

Immunity from prosecution for Dr. Taub. So, they will squeeze Sheldon Silver.

Dr. Taub was my personal oncology doctor for two years. From 1/1/75 monthly visits every Friday. At Mount Sinai in NYC. Ostensibly to treat melanoma. BCG. Bogus. Useless and expensive. I believe they knew this.

Medicine is deeply troubled. His peer should have known.

I was an employee of NY Presbyterian Hospital from 2005 to 2008, so Dr. Taub was known to me when my late sister contracted peritoneal mesothelioma a devastating and fatal illness, that attacks the lining of the abdominal organs. In spite of accepting tax payer funded "secret grant money" from Sheldon Silver, Dr. Taub did not and would not accept my sisters private insurance. I had informally appealed to the Chief Medical Officer, who I worked closely with at the time, but nothing could be done. True to form, Dr. Taub only took cash. In this respect he appears to have been very consistent. It should be noted that Dr Taub was only one of two practitioners on the east coast who claimed to treat mesothelioma, a Dr. Alexander was the other, at the University of Maryland. The truth is there is no specific treatment for it. Even Sloan Kettering had no treatment options. According to the the doctors at Sloane Kettering, Mesothelioma is not a true carcinoma, and the only treatment was extensive surgery and conventional chemo therapy much the same as is used to treat ovarian cancer.  We took my sister to Baltimore and she was treated there, but sadly she succumbed.  As for Dr. Taub and NY Presbyterian, as it were, they are now thinking, only of themselves. Dr. Taub is a government witness, granted immunity, and NY Presbyterian scapegoats and fires one of their own to salvage the organization's reputation. It seems it's still very cozy in Sheldon Sliver's universe of graft.
No cleansing. Just some shake, rattle and row.
And Putin warned him about Afghanistan.

Julie, Salutations.
The whole thing was a well-laid plan by the friends of occupiers of Palestine. The Arab spring was a hoax. These were allusions meant to delude the on-lookers and, with Saudi help, destroy each and every country that could conceivably stand up against continued occupation of Palestine. After Iraq, and Libya, it is now Syria turn. When the Saudis have served the America purpose, America will smartly walk out and claim it never had any commitments to the Saudi-Royals. And in the turmoil that follows, the House of Hasham, the House of Saud will be no more, and the occupiers of Palestine will have gained more slaves to work for them

Julie, some good points, but it was actually Mubarak of Egypt that cautioned GWB against invading Iraq, explaining that would create tens of thousands of Bin Ladens. But you're right, Bush-Cheney had a decade long plan and they were not going to bother with facts and logic.

King Abdullah actually cautioned Obama about destabilizing Egypt in 2011, and he was right because this administration was naive enough to think that aligning with the Muslim Brotherhood was going to be more beneficial. The MB is the organization that gave birth to Al-Qaeda, Hamas, and ISIS. Talk about choosing strange bed fellows to achieve stability.

Interesting that a world expert on the area, King Abdullah, directly warned GWB about Iraq.
We went in anyway, overriding experts, knowing it would likely be catastrophic.
The more we learn, the worse it is.

Why does the government owe anyone cheap rent?  The complainers seem to think that the rents are outrageous.......which they are.....but if no one rents them the rents will drop.  There are plenty of places in the  boroughs that are very reasonable and need gentrification.  Farther afield we have Paterson N.J. and many other locations in North Jersey where rent is cheap and access to the city is easy.

The sheer architectural banality of most of these new apartment buildings is overwhelming. Most are too boring and indistinct to even warrant the term "ugly." But to my mind they are a far greater insult to the city than the preposterous rents. We all don't have to live in them, but we all have to look at them. At least when we're not looking at our smart phones.

The picture of QLIC and adjacent buildings in Long Island City, is a typical example of the spirit-deadening streetscapes developing, particularly in the "hot" areas of the outer boroughs. I'm old enough to remember when a very nice two- or three-bedroom apartment in most of the better neighborhoods of Brooklyn and Queens could be had for about $225+ a month. Usually in a building with some character. Your "heated pergola" was your huge bathroom with luxurious cast iron tubs and steam radiators. The sun got through to the streets. You played basketball in an unsanitized, unrestricted neighborhood park.

"Amenity creep." Perfect phrase for a creepy time in New York City.

I just rented a great 1 bedroom 645 sq ft. 1 bedroom for my daughter on the UWS. W 70's. vibrant .exciting ..What a fabulous city we have.

$3400 a month Pre war, and we love it..

I prefer to own.

My 2 bedroom Eastside duplex is now avail. for 2.6 mill.
I paid 1.3 in 2007..

No rush to sell. so have a great day
And seniors who want to downsize.
Designer yuppieholes, anyone?
@maryann, Don't get too upset about who's being exploited, since we know these kids are almost all heavily to completely subsidised by the Bank of Mom and Dad.
